text:
Q: Parse error: syntax error, unexpected '|', expecting variable (T_VARIABLE) Symfony PHP VERSION WAMP Windows A:

this can be easily fixed by vi /usr/share/php/Composer/IO/BaseIO.php

and vi /usr/share/php/Psr/Log/LoggerInterface.php

and remove anything similar to Stringable|

and the composer works again.

Q: Unable to execute shell_exec A:

For the "errors" you encountered (on the screen dumps):

The syntax error you see in the command-line console is due to the fact that shell_exec is a PHP command for executing shell command from PHP. But what you are doing is you are ALREADY in the shell (not from PHP) so there is no point to do that.

So if you are in PHP, this will work:

<?php
echo shell_exec('ls -l');
?>

But if you are in the command-line console: the following will return an error:

[root@www ~]# shell_exec('ls -l');
-bash: syntax error near unexpected token `'ls -l''

instead, you should simply use the following:

[root@www ~]# ls -l

By the way

(1) the $item variable are not having any value assigned in the PHP code you posted.

(2) it appears that there are some special characters in the data passed to the shell_exec function in your PHP script, which may sometimes cause problems. The way to tackle it is to use escapeshellarg(), such as

//  $_GET['file1'] may contain special chars like '`' or ';'

$filename = escapeshellarg($_GET['file1']);
$output = shell_exec("ls -l " . $filename);

Q: How do I resolve .husky/_/husky.sh: No such file or directory error? A:

In my case the git config --local core.hooksPath returned just .husky (where a pre-commit file resides). My husky.sh file locates in .husky/_/.

I changed the GIT's core.hooksPath value to .husky/_ and it worked. The corresponding GIT command was git config --local core.hooksPath .husky/_.

Hope, it will help.

Q: Why doesn't my float comparison work in C? A:

... it's incorrect, only sometimes though.

  1. Read using fgets() to well consume a line of input, be it well formatted or not. scanf("%*s"); does not well consume errant input in a line.
if (scanf("%f", &input) != 1) {
  scanf("%*s");   //I dont understand why this fixes the infinite loop :(
  printf("Thats not a number!\n");
  continue;
}
  1. Save time, enable more warnings.

Example: gcc -std=c23 -O1 -g3 -pedantic -Wall -Wextra -Wconversion -Wlogical-op -Wsign-conversion -Wwrite-strings -c ...

Certainly "warning: 'result' may be used uninitialized" is a serious error.

test.c:17:23: warning: conversion from 'double' to 'float' changes value from '9.9999999999999995e-7' to '9.99999997e-7' [-Wfloat-conversion]
   17 | const float EPSILON = 0.000001;
      |                       ^~~~~~~~
test.c:18:18: warning: conversion from 'double' to 'float' may change value [-Wfloat-conversion]
   18 |     float absA = fabs(a);       // get absolute value of a & store to variable
      |                  ^~~~
test.c:19:18: warning: conversion from 'double' to 'float' may change value [-Wfloat-conversion]
   19 |     float absB = fabs(b);       // get absolute value of b & store to variable
      |                  ^~~~
test.c:20:18: warning: conversion from 'double' to 'float' may change value [-Wfloat-conversion]
   20 |     float diff = fabs(a-b);     // get absolute value of a-b (absolute value of epsilon) & store to variable
      |                  ^~~~
test.c:29:43: warning: conversion from 'double' to 'float' changes value from '3.4028229999999999e+38' to '3.40282306e+38f' [-Wfloat-conversion]
   29 |         return diff / fminf((absA + absB),3.402823e+38) < EPSILON; // check if diff is greater than epsilon*
      |                                           ^~~~~~~~~~~~
test.c: In function 'main':
test.c:38:11: warning: conversion from 'time_t' {aka 'long int'} to 'unsigned int' may change value [-Wconversion]
   38 |     srand(time(NULL));
      |           ^~~~~~~~~~
test.c:49:22: warning: conversion from 'int' to 'float' may change value [-Wconversion]
   49 |             result = number1 + number2;
      |                      ^~~~~~~
test.c:53:22: warning: conversion from 'int' to 'float' may change value [-Wconversion]
   53 |             result = number1 - number2;
      |                      ^~~~~~~
test.c:57:22: warning: conversion from 'int' to 'float' may change value [-Wconversion]
   57 |             result = number1 * number2;
      |                      ^~~~~~~
test.c:80:11: warning: 'result' may be used uninitialized [-Wmaybe-uninitialized]
   80 |         if(input != result){
      |           ^
.test.c:43:11: note: 'result' was declared here
   43 |     float result;
  1. Code like absA + absB < 1.1754944e-38 in floatComparison() takes the float out of floating point. It is always false unless absA and absB are near zero.

To compare 2 float and see if they are within +/- 1 ULP, consider:

#include <math.h>

bool floatComparison(float a, float b){
  if (isnan(a) || isnan(b)) return false; // Either not-a-number?
  // Compare `float` after and toward `b` to `b`.
  return nextafterf(a, b) == b; 
}
  1. "My expected outcome is that I'm able to compare floats up to the sixth decimal point."

That is a roughly correct idea yet insufficient to code by.

Two floats are compared using all of their binary digits (as well as exponent and sign). So first consider how the code with decimal digits is converted to binary. With float that is usually about 24 binary digits or about 1 part in 224 (~16,000,000).

Aside:

Run spell checker.
Code format looks good, although an auto formatter would be better.

Q: Error when opening a VSCode remote-container from a project using a Dockerfile and devcontainer.json A:

This solved the error for me:

sudo snap install docker

Q: hdfs namenode -format error (no such file or directory) A:

Update PATH in bashrc:

  • Add Hadoop to your PATH in ~/.bashrc: 
    export HADOOP_HOME=/usr/local/hadoop
export PATH=$PATH:$HADOOP_HOME/bin:$HADOOP_HOME/sbin
  • Reload your bash settings: 
    source ~/.bashrc

Check hadoop-env.sh:

  • Open hadoop-env.sh and make sure the paths are set correctly, especially JAVA_HOME: 
    export JAVA_HOME=/path/to/your/java
export HADOOP_HOME=/usr/local/hadoop
export HADOOP_CONF_DIR=$HADOOP_HOME/etc/hadoop

Run hdfs namenode -format
